data.title: The MPH Top 50: The 50 Best Alternative & Indie Songs of 2016
data.meta_description: We've scoured the world for the best indie tracks from 2016, with artists representing all corners of the US, as well as New Zealand, England, Wales, Australia, Sweden, France, and multiple selections from South Africa. But we've never been shy about the amazing music coming from the Great White Indie North, and this year's listâ€¦
data.meta_site_name: December's End: The Year's Music Best-Of's
data.text:
Jumps:

STFU and take me right to the damn list already: #50 â€“ #36 | #35 â€“ #21 | #20 â€“ #1

What else do you have besides the Top 50? Show me this yearâ€™s superlatives.

I donâ€™t wanna sit through any of that, just let me view the YouTube and Spotify playlists.

Welcome to the 5th annual MPH Top 50: The Yearâ€™s Music Best-Ofâ€™s, our published-one-a-year blog highlighting our (very subjective) picks for the 50 best indie and alternative tracks of the last 12 months. Has it really been five years of Decemberâ€™s End, half-a-decade of dissecting the yearâ€™s best? Itâ€™s quite a collection, the 260 amazing songs weâ€™ve spotlighted. Although published only annually, we spend most of the year thinking about what will make the list. Every new song we hear â€“ on the radio, sent to us by a friend, live from some unknown opening act â€“ stays in the back of our minds, mentally ranking it among the yearâ€™s music, vying for a spot in our countdown (thatâ€™s no jokeâ€¦ this yearâ€™s list contains a song released on New Years Day and two just in December alone). In those five years, weâ€™ve talked to many of our honorees about their spots on the list, and weâ€™re always humbled when they remember our selections.

Weâ€™ve scoured the world for the best indie tracks from 2016, with artists representing all corners of the US, as well as New Zealand, England, Wales, Australia, Sweden, France, and South Africa. But weâ€™ve never been shy about the amazing music coming from the Great White Indie North, and this yearâ€™s list is no exception with over a dozen spots occupied by Canadian artists. Ohhhhhhhhhhhh Canada.

Weâ€™re excited to have a brand new artist to our Top 50 topping this yearâ€™s list, joining our previous chart-toppers Rah Rah, Arkells, July Talk, and Hannah Georgas. But first, letâ€™s start at the bottom, where we find a trio of bands from the good olâ€™ US, representing New Orleans, Los Angeles, and Portland.

Numbers 50 â€“ 36:

# 50 | Light Up | Mutemath | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

For a band thatâ€™s been around for 15 years, Mutemath â€“ sorry, MUTEMATH â€“ maintains a very young and new sound, and this single finds a comfortable place in the indie pop catalogue of 2016, with an electronica Death Cab / M83 sound sprinkled with good late â€™70s R&B. Frontman Paul Meany wrote this track about his relationship with his wife of 17 years, a â€œreality check for the work that goes into turning the initial spark of attraction into a lasting loveâ€. That sounds like a recipe for band success as well.

Fun Fact: Mutemathâ€™s original name was just Math, which oddly was also our worst subject in school.

# 49 | True Confessions | Blondfire | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

If Garbage were starting out their career right now, this is what Shirley Manson and company would sound likeâ€¦ just with a little less California. Quietly releasing an EP of new material in March, Blondfireâ€™s Driscoll siblings take a very familiar sound and find a new way to pull it off, recalling that great era of â€™90s female synthpop from acts like Republica and Elastica. Placing their 6th song on our countdown in the last 5 years, Blondfire seem finally poised for a big breakout with their radio-friendly dreamy west coast beach sound.

Fun Fact: Bruce Driscoll â€“ half of the sibling-led band â€“ has a side project called Freedom Fry with French singer Marie Seyrat.

# 48 | White Flag | Joseph | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

This yearâ€™s Haim, the band Joseph consists of three sisters from Portland: Natalie, Allison, and Meegan Closner. Sibling bands always find love on our countdown (see Tegan & Sara, Rah Rah, Kâ€™s Choice, Kongos, Broods, Mother Mother, the aforementioned Blondfire) probably because sibling bands produce a unique, easy sound borne of years of sibling bonding that most bands struggle to build throughout long careers. Joseph is no exception. Having a quietly big year, â€˜White Flagâ€™ premiered on NPRâ€™s Songs We Love, hit #1 on the Adult Alternative chart, and grabbed a spot on Spotifyâ€™s Viral Top Ten. A song about â€œfacing what scares youâ€, this acoustic NPR-ready romp worms its way up through its rousing singalong and go-do-something inspirational chorus, right out of the Dixie Chicks / Indigo Girls songbook.

Fun Fact: The sisters in-laws in Brooklyn have a cat named Dingus.

# 47 | Genghis Khan | Miike Snow | ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

If you donâ€™t know by now, Miiiiiiiike Snow is not a person, but â€“ like many modern indie acts such as Chvrches â€“ are a duo of DJâ€™s and a frontman/singer. This one consists of the Swedish producing pair of Bloodshy & Avant and New York based singer Andrew Wyatt. This track â€“ their biggest of the year, comes off like a less-weird, less-complicated Gorillaz track, a rollicking mover about adolescent trust issues. I mean in 2016, why not have a light-hearted song about a genocidal megalomaniac?

Fun Fact: Bloodshy & Avant also produced Britney Spearsâ€™ â€œToxicâ€ and Katy Perryâ€™s â€œLove Meâ€.

# 46 | Sure and Certain | Jimmy Eat World | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

D.E. Top 50 contributor Shannon DeVido â€“ a self-described Jimmy Eat World obsessive fan â€“ disagrees with us about this track. We think this sounds very different from previous JEW releases, whereas she believes the track surely and certainly sounds exactly like classic JEW. Whichever way you lean, there is no doubting that not only is this one of Jimmy Eat Worldâ€™s catchiest songs since their heyday, and a wonderful return to form. A much-needed updating of that â€™90s Modern Rock sound that seems perfectly at home on a Live, Collective Soul, Eve 6, or Silverchair disc from 1996, the Jimmies crafted one of the best pure indie pop choruses of the year.

Fun Fact: When the bandmates were kids, vocalist Jim Adkinsâ€™ brother drew a picture on guitarist Tom Lintonâ€™s younger brother Jimmyâ€™s bedroom door, of Jimmy putting a globe in his mouth, and wrote â€œJimmy Eat Worldâ€, bing bang boom, thereâ€™s your name.

# 45 | Radio Kids | Strand of Oaks | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

The latest addition to the list, â€˜Radio Kidsâ€™ by Philadelphia-based songwriter/producer Timothy Showalter a/k/a Strand of Oaks, was only just released on December first, a late addition to our list nominees. From the explosive opening notes, this track takes you by the collar and demands you follow. Breaking in head-first with chaotic machinegun guitar strumming (very similar to Wintersleepâ€™s â€˜Santa Feâ€™, which comes later), a full-on dive into punk chaos makes way for an ethereal riff line (a sound used to great effect by phellow Philly acts Kurt Vile and War On Drugs) punctuated by breathy, strained vocals, Showalter channels â€˜Alex Chiltonâ€™-era Replacements to near perfection.

Fun Fact: In 2003, Showalterâ€™s house burned down, so he lived in hotels and on park benches while working at an orthodox Jewish day school.

# 44 | Canâ€™t Say | Letters to Cleo | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

Following last yearâ€™s outstanding return by â€™90s darlings Veruca Salt, 2016 had unexpected and wonderful comebacks from two more â€™90s female-fronted indie-jangle rock bands â€“ Tanya Donellyâ€™s Belly and Kay Hanleyâ€™s Letters To Cleo. While Belly only teased new music while out of their first tour in 21 years, LtC graced us with a full-blown EP (Back to Nebraska) and this wonderful single, their first in 17 years. Ben Wyatt would highly approve of this Letters to Cleo track that doesnâ€™t sound different from anything else played on the rooftop of Stadium High School in 1999.

Fun Fact: Vocalist Kay Hanley has had quite a varied career, including providing vocals for songs in the 2001 film Josie and the Pussycats, as well as on the kids shows Generation O!, My Friends Tigger and Pooh, Care Bears: Oopsy Does It!, and Doc McStuffins, and on the title track to a Sonic the Hedgehog video game, as well as performing on a float in the Macyâ€™s Thanksgiving Parade and singing back-up for Miley Cyrus on Hannah Montana tours.

# 43 | Bad Decisions | Two Door Cinema Club | ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡ª

If there wasnâ€™t evidence of the influence of â€™70s R&B bands like Earth Wind and Fire (who are still making modern festival appearances) in todayâ€™s indie pop, just look up and down this list for entries from M83, Saint Motel, and Northern Irelandâ€™s Two Door Cinema Club, and youâ€™ll see it front-and-center. This moving and shaking dance track â€“ complete with Bee Gees / Frankie Valli-esque falsetto vocals â€“ builds on a smooth bass track and crafty song-smithing that updates a slick Sly Stone sound, infused with a bit of Prince, in the most wonderful way. Just donâ€™t call it disco (even though, yes, itâ€™s basically disco). But what is the song about? Frontman Alex Trimble says itâ€™s about â€˜weltschmertzâ€˜, the German word for being at odds with the world around you.

Fun Fact: Kanye West once blogged about how much he liked Two Door Cinema Club, even posting the video for â€˜I Canâ€™t Talkâ€™ on his website.

# 42 | Gone | Jr Jr | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

The sound of 2016 indie rock lies in crafty new-folk from bands like The Strumbellas and X Ambassadors. The group formerly known as Dale Earnhardt Jr Jr lies not too far distant from that sound, just with a little more dance, pep, and groove to it, a bit akin to last yearâ€™s Top 50 darling BÃ¸rns. Moving away from the more loose alternative sound of their past DEJJ incarnation, the newly-christened Jr Jr gifts us with this poppy boppy track, full of light and bounce. One of the most infectious tracks released this year, the synth riff whistling while it works forces involuntary grinning and handclapping. Even Dale Jr canâ€™t keep his hands on the wheel.

Fun Fact: NASCAR driver Dale Earnhardt Jr is a fan of the band formerly named for him. Jr Jr emailed him a personal note to assure him werenâ€™t making fun of him.

# 41 | Fire Escape | Andrew McMahon in the Wilderness | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

For once, a new album did not come with it a new band name for Andrew McMahon. Throughout his incarnations as â€Jackâ€™s Mannequin, â€Something Corporate, and as a solo artist, McMahon has maintained a rabid fan-base (much of it now-grown 2000â€™s teen girls looking for the voice that sang to and for them). But after his surprising and long-time-coming success of last yearâ€™s â€˜Cecilia and the Satelliteâ€™, this yearâ€™s new CD Zombies on Broadway was highly-anticipatedâ€¦ and that anticipation paid off with an outstanding followup. As boppy and bouncy as Jr Jrâ€™s â€˜Goneâ€™ but more anthemic, â€˜Fire Escapeâ€™ takes that to the next level of musical maturity while maintaining a childlike wonder undercurrent, almost ready for a Sesame Street remake treatment or Pixar movie soundtrack placement. A notorious hard-worker and Aaron Sorkin-like perfectionist, there are few artists that other musicians universally root success for more than McMahon. More synth-heavy than previous releases, the influence that comes from moving his home base from California to New York comes through in this fully-formed pop triumph.

Fun Fact: Andrew McMahon survived two near-tragedies: Thanks to early detection, he successfully won a battle against leukemia. McMahon also survived having written several songs for the NBC series Smash.

# 40 | PCH | Tokyo Police Club | ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

Letâ€™s get this little tidbit out of the way first: To raise money for the Red Cross, TPC played this song live in front of an audience at Torontoâ€™s Rally Gallery for 12 straight hours (thatâ€™s over 200 times in a row, folks), exchanging donations from fans for a chance to sing along with the band on stage. The first (but far from last) band from Canada on our countdown, TPC crafts a track that mixes their established loose college party indie sound (as heard in last yearâ€™s Top 50 entry â€˜Hot Tonightâ€™) with an influence of all those California bands that have indeed come of age along the Pacific Coast Highway itself, like Cayucas or Best Coast. TPC isnâ€™t inventing anything new with â€˜PCHâ€™ or creating high art (as evidenced by their new albumâ€™s name, Melon Collie and the Infinite Radness (Part 1)), itâ€™s just a lot of fun.

Fun Fact: On their first appearance on Late Show with David Letterman, the host introduced them as â€œToyota Police Clubâ€. As much as weâ€™re sure Toyota appreciated that, fellow Canuck Paul Schaffer corrected Dave with the right name.

# 39 | Stop Desire | Tegan and Sara | ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

Ok ok ok ok we know there are already hundreds of thousands of words on the internet about the Quin sistersâ€™ slow transition from indie folk darlings to full-on â€™80s pop glam icons. But hear us out. Much like Dylan fans when Uncle Bobby went electric, indie fans of The Con-era T&S booed the change, shattered their vinyl LPâ€™s, and burned their â€œGo steady with meâ€ t-shirts when 2014â€™s Heartthrob came out. But the only issue with Heartthrob was that it wasnâ€™t The Con or So Jealous. It was actually a wonderful piece of intelligent, well-written power-pop that still came with the bones of old indie T&S down at the core. But old-school Tegan & Sara fans would hear none of it. Now if Heartthrob was a transition disc, LY2D had no similar indie pedigree to speak of. It was pure Madonna, pure Cyndi Lauper. But it was also written by two strong, smart crafty songwriters. That hasnâ€™t changed. It may have us taken seeing Tegan & Sara live supporting this album to really get it, but the songs are still good, still superiorily crafted. Yes, itâ€™s pop, yes itâ€™s full of â€™80s Top 40 sounds and instrumentation (ugh enough with that Berlin synthesizer), but itâ€™s still full of the deep and important songwriting and subject matter weâ€™ve come to love from the twins, and it deserves your change to listen. Behind the shimmery-sheen production and bouncy â€™80s synth, â€˜Stop Desireâ€™ is the gem of the album, a sweet pop swinger with catchy licks and strong vocals, and super-hooky chorus. We get it. We miss Living Room and Dark Come Soon and Where Does The Good Go too. But donâ€™t let your FOP (fear of pop) keep you from giving the best pure pop album of the year a real try. We still love, you Quin Twins.

Fun Fact: Tegan and Sara appeared this summer on Larry King. Yes, that Larry King. And it was as uncomfortable as you think. Take a watch.

# 38 | Good Grief | Bastille | ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§

Bastilleâ€™s Bad Blood album was so massive, and â€˜Pompeiiâ€™ and the title track have remained such alternative radio staples, itâ€™s hard to believe that itâ€™s already a three year old disc. And for as giant as that CD was, it started to feel like Dan Smith and friends were in danger of fading, missing out on the coattails of that scorching debut (paging Mark Foster and his People) if they didnâ€™t jump on Bad Bloodâ€˜s success with a quick sophomore followup. But Bastille Dan knew more than we did, proving with Wild World that taking his time to create a wondrous second effort was worth the wait. The first single â€˜Good Griefâ€™ doesnâ€™t stray too far a foot from the sound of that debut, with just a few new wrinkles and a slightly sunnier beat than tracks featuring volcano-covered Italian cities and David Lynch shows as subject matter. The song incorporates a funked-up bassline and some light xylophone work with with some familiar words from Kelly LeBroc (which she actually sung with the band when they appeared on Ellen), a beautifully-harmonized chorus tease, and verses ripe with those uber-overpronounced British vocals. Telling the story of an old flame thatâ€™s still got her hooks in him, â€˜Good Griefâ€™ was certainly a harbinger of the hooks that Bastille still had in us, even three years after their debut.

Fun Fact: Bastilleâ€™s â€˜Pompeiiâ€™ is the music on-hold if you ring up their label Virgin Records.

# 37 | Got Your Number | Serena Ryder | ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

What a great, kickass track from Elle King. Iâ€™m sorry, hold pleaseâ€¦ Iâ€™m being told that this isnâ€™t Elle King, but badass Toronto singer Serena Ryder. There are very few songwriters today out of the Liz Phair / Bonne Raitt school that can make a song move and shake down the track like Ryder can (see 2012â€™s MPH Top 50 for her rock anthem â€˜Stompaâ€™), and in the five years since her last outing â€“ the underrated Harmony â€“ itâ€™s nice to see that her style and her penchant for rollicking hasnâ€™t faded. â€˜Got Your Numberâ€™ is freight train of indie blues that showcases Ryderâ€™s smokey, raspy vocals on top of some top-notch acoustic blues rhythm guitar work. Maybe the new year will grace us with Ryder and Elle King on stage somewhere burning down the house together.

Fun Fact: In 2015, Ryder performed a live TV concert called â€˜The Quietest Concert Ever on the Ocean Floorâ€™, which had her standing on the ocean floor during low tide at the Bay of Fundy in New Brunswick, Canada, home of the worldâ€™s largest and fastest tidal change. A helicopter airlifted in equipment as soon as the tide receded as audience members descended cliffs to reach the floor via 151-step staircase. As soon as Ryder played her last song, crews raced to get everything back off the floor before tide waters rushed back in.

# 36 | Ophelia | Lumineers | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

We were never fans of The Lumineers. At times boring, at times pretentious. Itâ€™s as if in 2012, someone told a roomful of A&R guys â€œHey, go find us the next Mumford & Sonsâ€ and grabbed Lumineers off the (dirty, dirty) street. But with their second album Cleopatra, a more mature, more understated Lumineers have emerged. With both the first two singles, the title track and â€˜Opheliaâ€™, that same Lumineers sound has been updated, tighter and crisper-produced but still rootsy and rustic, finally giving credence to those calling The Lumineers the new The Band (and not just because The Band also recorded a track called â€˜Opheliaâ€˜). Theyâ€™re not quite there yet, but on this piano-driven, head-bopping slice of Americana, this Denver-based threesome and their studio friends are well on itâ€™s way.

Fun Fact: Wesley Keith Schultz tells the story of the bandâ€™s name: â€œWe were playing a club in Jersey City and there was a band called Lumineers slotted for the same time, same day, the next week. The person running the show that night mistakenly announced us as The Lumineers. The name stuck.â€

Numbers 35 â€“ 21:

# 35 | White Lights | Rural Alberta Advantage | ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

There are few bands consisting of just an acoustic guitar, keyboards, and drums that elicit as much power, determination, and strength as Torontoâ€™s The RAA. To see them live is to witness music in its purest form. The power of the trio comes differently from three directions, brand-spanking-new keyboardist Robin Hatch (ably replacing the sadly-departed Amy Cole), perpetual-motion-machine Paul Banwatt behind the drum kit, and guitarist / singer / songwriter Nils Edenloff, who embodies everything that bridges Canadian folk with indie rock. In 2014, The RAA grabbed our MPH Album of the Year with the subtle and soaring Mended with Gold. The new RAA album â€“ of which this is the title track â€“ wonâ€™t be released until well into 2017, and in fact, havenâ€™t even released a proper single for it yet. â€˜White Lightsâ€™ was soft-released in conjunction with a video compilation clip culled from their 8-date warm-up tour of the US to get some practice playing the new music live. Weâ€™re thankful they gave us the tease of this beautiful acoustic folk-rocker that bodes well for another stellar release in the coming year.

Fun Fact: Before forming The RAA, each of the three original members separately hosted open stage nights at a 120-year old Toronto club that closed within the year (they swear it wasnâ€™t their fault). The club is now a Tim Hortonâ€™s.

# 34 | Send My Love (To Your New Lover) | Adele | ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§

Yes, Adele. You read that correctly. We didnâ€™t expect to see her here either. Adele is fine in her genre. Sheâ€™s got an amazing voice, sheâ€™s a pop icon whose age you always know by her album title. But donâ€™t forget, Adele Laurie Blue Adkins burst on to the (US) scene in 2010 with â€˜Rolling In The Deepâ€™, which for as bluesy and angry it was, wasnâ€™t pop (despite the charts). That was alternative. And it was good. Frankly, most of what sheâ€™s recorded since, despite the incredible voice, was boring. And pop. Boring pop. Tell me â€˜Helloâ€™ isnâ€™t boring af. But â€˜Send My Loveâ€™ has indie written all over it. It could be recorded by Lorde or any of 2016â€™s chanteuses, like Bishop Briggs or K.Flay or Halsey. But Adele can sing better than any of those youngsters. The light electronic pulse ne acoustic octave riff through the verses pervades the entire track with a beat and feel that just envelops you into the song entirely, at home with any blues beat from Elle King or Amy Winehouse. And only sets the table for the swooping chorus, teased into invitingly and releasing masterfully with a vocal performance only Adele could pull off in one of the catchiest refrains recorded this year. It remains a mystery to us how this track did not cross over to alternative radio. The reason most likely is that it comes on a CD with the name â€˜Adeleâ€™ plastered all over it.

Fun Fact: Adele claims she stopped reading books at the age of six. The last book she remembers reading was Roald Dahlâ€™s Matilda.

# 33 | Carry On | CÅ“ur de pirate | ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

Speaking of indie chanteuses, we would like to introduce you to one you probably have never heard of. CÅ“ur de pirate is BÃ©atrice Martin, a 27-year-old Francophone singer from MontrÃ©al. Sheâ€™s been active for a decade, has five albums to her credit, two Juno nominations, and four FÃ©lix Awards. And she almost exclusively records in French. Which â€“ as we mentioned â€“ is why you probably havenâ€™t heard of her. But not being from QuÃ©bec, Martinique, or France, we were very fortunate that Martin, whose stage name translates to â€˜Her Pirate Heartâ€™, released this wonderful track â€˜Carry Onâ€™ in both French and English. A beautiful indie electronic track with nasal, breathy vocals over an easy-flowing synth beat, had she been an English recording artist â€“ again, in the 2016 of Bishop Briggs, K.Flay, and Halsey â€“ thereâ€™s a good chance she would have had a massive US hit with this cut.

Fun Fact: In 2009, Martin received a CBC â€˜Buckyâ€™ Awards for â€œBest Reason to Learn Frenchâ€ and â€œSexiest Artistâ€, for which we do not disagree.

# 32 | Miracle | Darcys | ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

Thank god for music friends. We would not have been introduced to this art rock duo from Ontario if not for recommendations of friends north of the border. The Darcys have been kicking around for half a decade, running in circles with bands like July Talk and Hannah Georgas and Mother Mother, but have finally snagged the mainstream success in Canada theyâ€™ve been verging on for a couple years. That being said, this might be the same band from their beginnings in name only. In between 2013â€™s Warning and the new disc Centerfold, The Darcys slimmed down from three permanent members to two, and completely changed their sound. Fortunately, the bandâ€™s existing fanbase seemed to almost unanimously welcome the shift in musical direction. And what great timing. It takes about 5 seconds into â€˜Miracleâ€™ to pick up on the George Clinton-style dance influence of the discâ€™s lead single, directly in line with the discoization of alternative music in 2016 from bands like M83, Saint Motel, Two Door Cinema Club, and Fitz & The Tantrums. With a fat driving dance bassline, punchy-crunchy keyboards, sharp falsetto backing vocals, and groove, The Darcys gave us a near-perfect alt-funk track.

Fun Fact: Darcys Wes Marskell contributes articles to The Huffington Postâ€˜s Canada Music section.

# 31 | Absolutely | Ra Ra Riot | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

We just love that the quirky artsy rockers from Syracuse University (our alma mater) returned to success this year with this energetic track. â€˜Absolutelyâ€™ strays a bit away from some of the baroque pop style of their previous biggest single â€˜Too Dramaticâ€™, but the cello-and-string infusion is happily still a strong part of their sound. Somewhere between old Jimmy Eat World and new Andrew McMahon with a hint of Death Cab, Wes Miles and his companions craft a fairly mainstream synthpop slice of happiness, which they released on New Years Day 2016 as part of a Spotify playlist of some of their fav tracks from some of their fav artists.

Fun Fact: Itâ€™s no wonder they have a bit of a Death Cab sound, as their 2010 release The Orhard was mixed by now-former Death Cab member Chris Walla.

# 30 | Liana | Joy Formidable |

The Joy Formidable have been compared to a range of other artists from Belle and Sebastian to BjÃ¶rk, but there is no doubt at all that this album track from 2016â€™s Hitch is purely from the Stevie Nicks volume of the Fleetwood Mac playbook, complete with Lindsay Buckingham influence in Rhydian Dafyddâ€™s outstanding guitar break, Christine McVie-style keys, and work from drummer Matt Thomas who has never not heard the parallels to Mick Fleetwood, in style and in temperament (even if he looks and sounds more like Russell Brand). And that doesnâ€™t even begin equating Ritzy Bryanâ€™s wonderful Stevie-style whispy, breathy, and powerful vocals. In the way that Led Zeppelin did before them, TJF has always walked the fence between crushing power riff hard rock (â€˜Cradleâ€™, â€˜Little Blimpâ€™) and extremely delicate almost operatic compositions (â€˜Wolfâ€™s Lawâ€™, â€˜Silent Treatmentâ€™), but few have melded both styles as well as this stellar track from the Welsh threesome.

Fun Fact: In 2008, TJF released a Christmas single called â€˜My Beerdrunk Soul Is Sadder than a Hundred Dead Christmas Treesâ€™. We feel you.

# 29 | Welcome To Your Life | Grouplove | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

Man, we canâ€™t ever get enough of Grouplove. They put together two of our favorite performances at this yearâ€™s Firefly Festival in Dover Delaware (one main stage, one acoustic tentâ€¦ something theyâ€™ve done on the regular before). Thatâ€™s why it amazes us that theyâ€™ve only appeared on the MPH Top 50 twice before (â€˜Itchinâ€™ on a Photographâ€™ from Never Trust a Happy Song, and â€˜Ways to Goâ€™ from Spreading Rumours). Part of that falls on a small hiatus the band took so singers Hannah Hooper and Christian Zucconi could reproduce. Itâ€™s always a question of will the sound or songwriting of a band change when the chief songwriters have a baby together, will the style become softer or take fewer risks? Thankfully, the answer for Grouplove was a resounding â€˜noâ€™, nothingâ€™s gonna change. And that shouldnâ€™t surprise us from this group of former artists commune roommates (srsly, they all met at an artist residency in Crete). While their sound is still a Big Mess, as the new disc is titled, this collection of sloppy, jangly, messy parts â€“ as always â€“ comes together as a very unique whole. â€˜Welcome To Your Lifeâ€™ is indeed a greeting to Willa Payne Zucconi entering the world, and weâ€™re always happy to have Grouplove â€“ ever positive, ever optimistic â€“ as part of ours.

Fun Fact: While Hooper and Zucconi wrote the music and the verses, drummer Ryan Rabin wrote the chorusâ€¦ in the shower at the exact time he knew Hooper was giving birth.

# 28 | The Drugs | Mother Mother | ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

Weâ€™ll start with a little criticismâ€¦ what made us fall immediately in love with the first two singles from 2014â€™s Very Good Bad Thing, â€˜Get Out The Wayâ€™ and â€˜Monkey Treeâ€™, were the risks they took, the odd instrumentation (something not unusual for the unusual Mother Mother), the bold sounds, the different directions. Upon first listen to â€˜The Drugsâ€™, the first single released from 2017â€™s upcoming disc No Culture, we heardâ€¦ sameness, straightforwardnessâ€¦ the usual. It was disappointing for this highly-anticipated new music from the Guldemond siblings and the rest of the band (including new bassist Mike Young). But as happens on occasion, we heard the song over again, many times, and we just couldnâ€™t get enough of itâ€¦ much like the songâ€™s titular drugs we used to love. This is actually a return to O My Heart-era MM, which delightfully mixed uncomplicated rock with chances. And thatâ€™s why we find here. â€˜The Drugsâ€™ moves like a pure rock song, and straightforward lyrics that are quite simply about, well, when chief songwriter Ryan Guldemond was not just deep in the drugs, but, as he says, â€œthings that offer fleeting joy but lasting consequence. Drugs, alcohol, hollow sex, ice creamâ€. It might take you a few listens, but weâ€™re sure that youâ€™ll be hooked on â€˜The Drugsâ€™ (sorry, we had to make the joke, itâ€™s like an addiction).

Fun Fact: O Canada Magazine once posited that Mother Mother was The Most Hated Band in Canada. Take that, Nickelback!

# 27 | Rebel Heart | Shelters | ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

Yes, the opening licks of this song sound exactly like The Beatles â€˜I Feel Fineâ€˜ and The Monkees â€˜Last Train To Clarksvilleâ€˜. But thatâ€™s where the comparison endsâ€¦ or does it?
